content: It's hard to be prepared for that question. I feel more ready for it now, aware of its intent, having heard others' experiences. It's something many Asian Americans are speaking up about. Yet, you don't fully grasp its implications until it happens to you personally. Answering this question is challenging as it seems to question your identity, which I believe isn't the best approach. It depends on who's asking, but overall, it's hard to provide a definitive answer.
concept: Asian American experience, identity questioning, personal implications
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: Sure, many people ask, "Where are you from?" and even after I reply, "From the U.S." they follow up with, "Where are you actually from?" It's an assumption that I wasn't born here, even though I was. People usually expect me to say "China" when they inquire about my cultural identity. This happens frequently, based on appearances. I believe many Asian Americans born here have had similar experiences.
concept: Asian American experience, cultural difference, racial identity
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: Verbal communication incidents were more common in my experience, not physical assault or attacks. These instances often didn't feel significant enough to bring up, but I believe many people encounter this form of verbal discrimination as a kid. It wasn't one person consistently mistreating me, but rather different occurrences. This is a common issue for immigrants, especially second-generation ones.
concept: immigrant experience, second-generation immigrant, verbal discrimination
ls: Adolescence, Early school years, Young adulthood
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: As a minority, I didn't have many people to discuss my experiences with. This often led to feelings of embarrassment, being one of the few who looked a certain way or ate specific food. Now, as I interact with more friends who share similar experiences, I've grown proud of my background and cherish the stories I can share. Looking back, I realize there's no reason for embarrassment. The feeling of embarrassment was more prominent than anger. Although there were occasions where I felt anger, retrospectively, I was more upset about the incidents. The intensity of my feelings varied depending on when it happened, be it in college, middle school, or high school.
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: There were instances of stereotypes and bullying due to my Asian American background. These incidents were sporadic, often in the form of verbal messages or interactions. Derogatory terms, like chink were sometimes used during basketball games. The impact of these words was more profound during childhood. It felt as though I was being judged by my appearance. While some might see these remarks as jokes, they generally conveyed a negative message. As a child, I felt a sense of embarrassment due to these experiences. It wasn't just about how I looked but also about my culture, the food I ate, and things associated with me. But now, I'm proud of my appearance and my culture.
concept: Asian American experience, stereotype, verbal discrimination
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: Building relationships and friendships through playing basketball was crucial for me. It strengthened my connection with my family. Even though we don't play as much now, we remain close. Part of this closeness is due to our shared love for basketball, a common language that brought us together. Following sports teams like the Washington Wizards also exposed me to other sports such as baseball, football, and soccer. Engaging in these Americanized sports helped me better adjust to the culture around me and resonate more with kids growing up in the same environment.
concept: Americanized, basketball, connection, culture, family, sports
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: The Chinese community in the DC area is shrinking rapidly, making it increasingly harder for them(parent), especially as English is not their first language. My dad initially worked in a restaurant, but as it became more challenging, he switched to carpentry. He took on various jobs, from construction to fixing pipelines and even making furniture, showcasing his versatility.
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: Reflecting on my parents' qualities, they were relaxed and recognized our need to adapt to our environment, which included speaking more English. However, we still attended a weekend Chinese school to learn Mandarin, despite struggling to fully grasp it. They offered other classes there, but it was primarily for Mandarin, not Cantonese. Cantonese isn't popular in the area where we lived.
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: We predominantly speak Cantonese with our parents, occasionally using English for words we don't know in Cantonese. Sometimes, especially with my younger brother, sentences would be half in Cantonese and half in English, which could be challenging to understand. In my case, I estimate about 80 to 90% of my communication was in Cantonese and the rest in English. This bilingual communication was mostly with my parents, as I felt more comfortable speaking to them.
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: Growing up, we recognized our parents' hard work. They labored tirelessly through our elementary, middle, and high school years. As we matured and required more financial support, we noticed their constant efforts even more. Unlike many of our school peers from wealthier families, our parents were not extremely wealthy, despite their dedication. This realization made us appreciate their efforts to raise us. This is a big deal for us, growing up as Asian Americans. We often found ourselves not only helping ourselves but also assisting our parents a lot since their English still isn't very good. For instance, helping our family with bills or translating was a significant part of our upbringing.
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: Regarding lunch preparation, we chose what we wanted to bring to school, which differed from the norm. My parents understood, recognizing that our experiences were distinct from theirs. They acknowledged our need to fit in through aspects such as food choices, assimilating with what other kids brought to school.
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: Indeed, we could relate to what you're talking about. My brothers and I often brought more westernized foods to school, such as peanut butter and jelly sandwiches, though these weren't typical at home meals. We also favored things like Lunchables, pre-prepared meals from grocery stores that were popular among kids. However, back then, we often felt embarrassed to bring lunch box with Asian food to school, a sentiment that has changed significantly today. When asked about the sense of embarrassment, it was more prominent during high school. We tended to bring more westernized food to fit in with our peers and see what they were bringing to school.
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: Growing up, I was fortunate to have a lot of exposure to various experiences from my elementary school years and upbringing. I found commonalities with my peers through shared interests, such as sports or school activities. We also bonded over similar experiences, like having the same teachers, navigating the same academic challenges, or pursuing similar paths in high school or careers. One of my closest friends in middle school and elementary school, who was also Asian, shared a passion for basketball. These commonalities throughout childhood really bring people together.
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: I enjoyed playing basketball and video games during school. Some of my close friends and I formed a high school basketball league. We played weekly games. Even though we never won a championship, we had a lot of fun. We made our own team and played a lot outside of school. My friends were diverse with Asian, Indian, Korean, and even Black backgrounds.
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: Friendship, to me, has been an intriguing journey. I moved once during my elementary school years, which led to a shift in my group of friends. As we progressed from elementary to high school, due to district boundaries, we often ended up in different schools. In high school, many of my friends attended different institutions, necessitating constant readjustments. My friends and I shared common interests like sports and video games, which meant that my friendships often revolved around basketball, watching sports, or playing Xbox games. These experiences led to a variety of friendships throughout elementary, middle, and high school, and a period of readjustment as we all moved to different schools.
ls: Adolescence, Early school years, Young adulthood
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: I began playing basketball in third grade, around the same time as my older brother. Our mutual competitiveness made us better players. We often kept score, constantly pushing each other to improve. This sport was a significant part of my upbringing, as my family, including my brothers and cousins, all shared an interest in playing and watching basketball.
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: Absolutely, he did and still does guide us in many ways. My elder brother took on the responsibility of navigating us through aspects of life that our parents, due to their unfamiliarity with the system here, couldn't advise on. I think that's an accurate depiction of his role. We attended the same schools from elementary through high school. Even in college, despite being on opposite coasts, I continued to seek his advice. I reached out for his guidance, a practice that didn't stop after high school.
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: Having two brothers is advantageous as it provided reinforcement when convincing our parents. If there was just one child, it would have been different. My older brother is very assured, great at conversation and making friends. His amiable nature attracts good people. He was a role model growing up. He's creative, enjoys designing, and is now making a career out of it. He was more artistic than me, often drawing and painting. These qualities define him well.
ls: Adolescence, Early school years, Young adulthood
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: We didn't often eat pasta, but we frequently enjoyed Asian food, particularly Chinese. We cherished home-cooked meals, particularly dishes like dumplings, rice meals, and noodle dishes. My favorite is the popular Cantonese dish, egg with tomato, which my dad often prepared. We also had a variety of foods from different cuisines, like Korean and Thai. Overall, my palate leaned heavily towards Asian cuisine.
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: We often celebrated with birthday cakes and home-cooked food, especially dumplings. Those were memorable family moments, preparing and enjoying dumplings together for different occasions. For big celebrations, we sometimes drove a long way to have dim sum. We also went out for dinner to mark special events.
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: Sometimes, I would save the money from the red envelope. I never spent it right away. It was like the tooth fairy tradition, where you kept it under the pillow for a while. I would leave the red envelope somewhere close, for good luck and energy. After some time, I would save the money. As a child, I didn't really spend it, except for the occasional video game. Usually, I just kept it until I needed it.
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: We primarily celebrated holidays like the Lunar New Year, significant in our culture. Celebrations usually involved family gatherings or dinners. Instead of conventional gifts, we received red envelopes on birthdays and holidays. These occasions were often marked by cooking and enjoying food together. My dad, a restaurant chef, had a passion for cooking. He often tried new recipes, resulting in a plethora of home-cooked Chinese meals. To me, the meanings of red envelope vary by location, but it's largely about good luck, health, and positive energy. Receiving it from parents, uncles, aunts, or grandparents feels significant. To boil it down, it signifies good health, luck, and positive energy.
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: It was challenging for my parents to guide us as they didn't grow up in the States and lacked experience with the education system, job market, and even the culture here. Their experiences were vastly different from ours, making it difficult for them to advise us. We mostly learned by ourselves, navigating through life figuring things out, as they couldn't share much from their own upbringing. The conversation wasn't largely centered around these topics. They occasionally offered advice, but it was usually after the fact. For instance, after we applied to colleges, they would advise on what we should do, where we should go, or which was a better financial option. However, they didn't provide much guidance about academics or the process of getting into school.
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: My parents were fairly liberal and open to what I chose to pursue. They weren't vocal about it, but there was an implicit understanding that I was probably going to pursue a career in technology. The hard work they put into raising us instilled in me and my brothers a desire to make them proud. This didn't translate into pressure, but rather an internal motivation to do our best. The idea of making them proud became more prominent during high school when we began thinking about our futures. Despite this, there was no high pressure on us as we were already performing well in school.
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: As a middle child, I feel I found a good balance. I received a lot of hand-me-downs but also enjoyed new experiences. I was fortunate to have supportive parents and brothers who cared for me, creating a well-rounded environment. I often emulated my older brother, from his style to his attitude, which shaped my growth. Despite only being a year apart, he was a role model for me, and I followed in his footsteps. We grew up in a similar environment, and many of my actions were influenced by him. Looking back, we shared many experiences and grew up closely.
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: It was indeed helpful having an older brother. Similarly, my younger brother, who used to be a bit of a goofball, has matured significantly. We looked to each other for assistance and guidance. He's an intelligent younger brother and I'm fortunate to have grown up with two wonderful brothers. If time permits, I have plenty of shared stories to tell.
title: Thesis Interviewee

content: That's a great question, it brings back fond memories. As kids, we'd fight occasionally but mostly for fun. We learned and grew from each other. An example would be playing basketball or going to the park to chat about our day. Since my older brother is only a year older, we went to the same schools and had similar experiences. Growing up in the states, having an older brother who had gone through things first was beneficial. He provided inspiration and a roadmap. With our parents being immigrants from China, they had less understanding of the education system here. However, having an older brother who went through it before me provided insights that helped me navigate school and my career after graduation.
title: Thesis Interviewee

It was unclear where he stood in this conversation, if anyone noticed him to begin with. Quotations about complicity, victimhood, and color-blind racism were lobbed across the room, accusations flew inches from his face, and he was in the middle of it, neither Black nor white, scrutinizing the gestures and details that nobody else picked up on.”

in the beginning of production, my father died, and this whole film was about thanking our parents, and that event was a surprise for my family. I hadn’t thought about it that way. I was a very naive and jerk kid to my parents, because growing up in that world I didn’t realize how hard it is. When my parents were telling me their stories of having survived the Korean War or they had nothing, I would say, “OK, can I play video games now?” I was that type of kid. 

The older I got, it started to sink in. How did they do this without knowing the language? When I got married and had kids, it started to dig into me about how much I appreciated what they had given. So, that opening was to show how hard it was for them, as outsiders coming into this new world.

content: “I got an email from someone saying, ‘Because it was doing so well in Korea, that your parents were looking down on you,’ so I started seeing it in a very different way. I lost both of my parents while making [this movie], so that it would do so well there meant the world to me,” said Sohn. “And now that it’s on Disney+, that people have come up to me and have reached through social media, connecting to this second-generation love story, has been overwhelming. You spend so much of your life doing this work, all you want to do is to connect.”

content: As second-generation immigrants, we try to navigate life with intense pressure to fit in, all the while trying to stay connected to our roots despite the overwhelming fear of being judged. We learn just how impossible it is to live up to our parents' expectations and to overcome the image society has of immigrants.
title: A third culture: Navigating second-generation identity

content: As I grew older, I met more of my extended family, having titas and titos (aunts and uncles for Filipinos) come over more often, I started to develop this sense of belonging that I once yearned for.
title: A third culture: Navigating second-generation identity

content: Whenever I would talk about art school, my parents told me to keep it as a hobby and that there was no money in art and that my career options were limited to becoming a doctor, an engineer or a lawyer– an omnipresent diatribe heard universally by the children of immigrants.
title: A third culture: Navigating second-generation identity

content: According to a 2016 census by https://www12.statcan.gc.ca/census-recensement/2016/as-sa/98-200-x/2016017/98-200-x2016017-eng.cfm, 16.9 percent of immigrants are reported to only know English and 59.6 per cent to know English and at least one other language. Oftentimes I wished my parents could have done more and encouraged me to learn, but I now know my parents only stripped me of my ancestry out of necessity. To survive, they, along with my sister and I, had to conform to western society.
title: A third culture: Navigating second-generation identity

content: "I, like many second-generation immigrants, was made to feel primitive or "FOB" – or Fresh off the Boat, a derogatory sentiment violently aimed at non-white communities who exist in predominantly white spaces– if we boasted about our culture and "whitewashed" if we did not know enough because we were forced to assimilate. See that's the thing about living in western society: no matter how inclusionary or diverse they appear to be, you’re made aware of your differences and that’s when the erasure of culture, conscious and subconscious, begins"
title: A third culture: Navigating second-generation identity

content: “If you came back, you wanted to leave again. If you went away, you wanted to come back. Wherever you were, you could hear the call of the homeland, like the note of a herdsman’s horn. Your true abiding place was the vision of something very far off And your soul was like the waves, always restless, forever in motion, Never at home.” “Only those who risk going too far can possibly find out how far they can go.”

content:
There is this cultural difference coming from overseas to the United States for schooling (as a TCK). You experience a lot of stereotypes. From my experiences in U.S. schools, teachers did not use my overseas experiences as lessons in the classrooms. There was an ignorance from teachers (particularly in high school) about cultures, especially Asian, and stereotypes of those cultures. Teachers were not welcoming to (curriculum) options other than what was written in textbooks. They did not use students as curriculum resources in learning. In the younger grades, I did not understand what was going on. But by eighth grade, I realized
that in general “something was missing” in my (U.S.) schooling experiences. I suppose a lot depends on the demographics of the school, community and teachers’ backgrounds as well as teachers’ knowledge of their students. Growing up in this (TCK) life and building trust with teachers is so important.
